Besty working for Jen Hsun? Pleeeease, don't flatter yourself, bugsy_best! Jen Hsun wouldn't want you to shine his shoes... Obviously you haven't the slightest idea that you are in fact sub-human.

Good find. Additional comments that the article should have included - NVIDIA graphics caters to Power Gamers who will NEVER play on an integrated X86GPU as noted. The Typical analyst equate the GPU business to the Chipset (North & South bridge) business that Nvidia exited because it’s integrated into the X86 CPU or intel offering a bundle. That business went rapidly to zero as seen in the annual revenue ~ 2010 – 2011. Unlike the chipset business – GPUs are highly performance and feature driven (ex. 3D). No Gamer cares about what chipset is in a desktop – so long as it performs the traffic control between the chips. So it’s easy to see the chipset biz instantly going away upon integration into the X86. High Powered GPUs have more computational power than the X86 CPU and it’s required to drive the advance Games so there you go – there will always be Power Gamers 50M to 100M of them and there will always be teams like the Nasa Curiosity that will always need high Power GPUs and teams like Pixar and Lucas Films that also needs them. So unlike Chipsets that disappeared and nobody cared - GPUs is here to stay. It will be a steady cash cow - growth will be at the expense of AMD who will eventually have to exit the market. The fact that Nvidia is migrating it's functionality to the cloud, super computing and industrial applications ensures that they have a reasonably large market so they can continue to develop and milk it and then reuse the technology in the mobile space as Kepler has done. The discrete notebook GPU space may eventually take a big hit as Intel goes to smaller geometry offering more GPU performance. However people like Apple and Alienware will always offer discrete GPU for serious apps.

In semi manufacturing - there are many yields involved 1) Fab Yield - how many wafers you start and how many ended up passing the WAT tests (wafer level acceptance tests) - any loss here the Fab eats it ie the customer only pays for wafers shipped 2) After the wafers are shipped - they are tested (wafer sort) rigorously - Typically if the wafers yields above an agreed on "minimum" yield the fab would not take the wafers. So it's in the interest of the customer to have a very high yield per wafer to lower the cost per part. The yield per wafer can NEVER be 95% on a product this complex and or on a new process unless the die size is ~ 4mm2 - in this case the GPU GT680 if I recall correctly is ~ 250mm2 ie yield sucks - they are lucky if they got 50% wafer yield. 3) After you are done with wafer sort - you go to packaging - there the packaging yield should be > 98% 4) Then you typically go for Final testing before shipping - here the yield should be > 95% but could be lower for a newer product. So the short story is - I am referring to the Wafer Fab Yield. I am used to seeing well above 95% on mature processes

The big story is the confirmation that 28nM fab yields was horrendous - even 80% is still pretty bad. I don't recall anytime in the past where Fab yields were even close to 80% on any process node. TSMC eats Fab losses - not the customer. Customer eats poor wafer sort yields. When fab yields are bad it typically translate into poor Wafer Sort yields as well. Reverse is true too which means GPU costs will likely improve.

Message.Title: Per comparative valuation, NVDA wins hands down!
Message.Msg: Based on five vital performance metrics (culled from YahooFi), the share price of NVDA is presently the cheapest when juxtaposed against 3 of its bigger rivals/peers, i.e., QCOM, TXN, & BRCM. 1) PE multiples: QCOM=18.7; TXN=21.9; BRCM=26.2; NVDA=19.3 2) Forward PE: QCOM=15.5; TXN=13.9; BRCM=11.6; NVDA=13.6 3) Price/Sales: QCOM=5.8; TXN=2.60; BRCM=2.70; NVDA=2.3 4) Price/Book: QCOM=3.3; TXN=3.10; BRCM=2.80; NVDA=2.1 5) Earnings growth (fye ’13): QCOM=12.4%; TXN=26%; BRCM=5.8%; NVDA=20%!!! Conclusion: It shouldn’t take another full Q for institutional investors to realize NVDA is playing its cards right; the stock value will be duly recognized before long. GLTA

- That has to be the skimpiest financial analysis of a company ever written. And I quote: Financial Metrics "Nvidia has $3.13B in cash or $5.06/share and only $20.8M in debt. Forward P/E (fye Jan 29, 2014) is 14.8." That's it? Cash and some guesstimated forward P/E? Ha ha ha ha ha! It's no wonder 90% of the posters here are so badly underwater. Did it go out of fashion to give a word or two about Actual Reported Earnings? Which PLUNGED 37% for the First Half 2012, on a year-year basis. Or mention the company's genuine P/E (ttm). Which is 19.29 times one year's earnings. According to Yahoo Finance. Or the current dividend yield on nvidia shares, perhaps? Which has been zero percent (0.00%) for an unbroken 18-year stretch. Or the Beta for this highly highly volatile stock. Of 1.87 -- nearly double the Market's volatility, right? Or maybe provide the reading audience a simple chart showing nvda's performance relative to the Market? Like every card-carrying CFA does. Like this one for example. http://finance.yahoo.com/q/bc?t=5y&s=NVDA&l=off&z=l&q=l&c=aapl&ql=1&c=%5EIXIC By the looks of it, the author John Heltzer is maybe some type of technical guy. But not of securities analysis. Oh no no no. Like the kind you call when your PC's printer is broken. Right before you leave for lunch. -
